Award.AwardTitle: Dissociating the Carbon Nanotube Exciton in Organic- and Inorganic- Semiconductor Blends
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: This project addresses the potential of CNT/polymer/inorganic composite materials for efficient photovoltaic operation. The approach includes: synthesis of blends of semiconducting carbon nanotubes with organic and inorganic semiconductors using wet chemical and solution-based blending techniques; characterization of the internal morphology of these blends as a function of processing conditions and materials selection; identification of composite materials that will form a type II (donor/acceptor) heterojunction with semiconducting carbon nanotubes; studies to determine mechanisms responsible for exciton dissociation and charge collection in carbon nanotube/semiconductor blends; quantification of rates for exciton dissociation, charge separation, and charge recombination in the blends; and, quantification of the electron affinity and ionization potential of monodisperse semiconducting carbon nanotubes. It is expected that photogenerated charge carriers in carbon nanotubes can be dissociated and collected by synthesizing donor/acceptor blends of semiconducting carbon nanotubes with more or less electronegative semiconductors. Emphasis is placed on understanding the interrelationship between synthesis, processing, composition, morphology, and properties of such blends. A variety of semiconductors will be investigated to complement the carbon nanotubes in the blends including fullerene-derivatives, semiconducting polymers, and semiconductor oxides. The morphology of the blends will be characterized via scanning probe and electron microscopy as a function of the processing conditions and materials selections. Electronic transport, photoluminescence quenching, spectrally resolved photocurrent, and transient photo-induced absorption measurements will be used to assess the optoelectronic properties of these materials.
Non-Technical: The project addresses basic research issues in a topical area of materials science having high technological relevance. The research will contribute basic materials science knowledge at a fundamental level to new understanding and capabilities for materials combinations with potential for improvements in conversion of solar power to electricity. The scientific investigations will also train students; in addition to supporting one graduate student, the project will promote teaching, training, and learning through the integration of undergraduate students into a research setting. The project also provides support for two summer students in the PI?s laboratory through UW-Madison's SURE/REU (Summer Undergraduate Research Experience and Research Experience for Undergraduates) program. The SURE/REU program primarily supports students in under-represented groups. Additionally, the project supports a UW-Madison undergraduate student for the academic year. Topics such as ethics, how to do research efficiently, problem solving, networking, research safety, experimental procedure, and results presentation will be integrated with day-to-day laboratory training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The results from this project establish the fundamental photophysical and materials principals for unlocking the potential of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) as light absorbers in thin film photovoltaic (PV) devices like solar cells and photodetectors. CNTs are narrow tubes comprised entirely of carbon that are about one billionth of a meter in diameter, which is so small that there are only 10’s of carbon atoms around their circumference. These nanomaterials are promising for light harvesting because by varying their diameter it is possible to tune the “color” of light that is absorbed and because these materials are strong light absorbers. Also, CNTs are attractive because of their economical solution-processability, ultrafast energy and charge transport, and excellent photostability. However, so far exploiting CNTs as photoabsorbers in devices beyond the single CNT level has been challenging because of metallic CNTs in ensembles of as-grown CNTs, which quench photoresponsivity, and because photogenerated charges in CNT films bind together as excitons (whereas these charges need to be unbound and separated to harvest energy or detect light).

 

In this project, we learned how to overcome these problems by (i) dramatically reducing CNTs’ structural and electronic heterogeneity using conjugated polymers (polyfluorenes) as differentiating agents and (ii) discovering how to efficiently separate the charges. We also (iii) determined the fundamentals of exciton energy flow and charge generation and collection in coupled CNT materials. We successfully identified electron acceptors, including C60-fullerenes and derivatives, that extract photogenerated electrons from CNTs with internal quantum efficiency (exciton to separated charge efficiency) of > 85% (and incident photon to separated charge efficiency as high as 50%). We learned that energy transport through a CNT film to an overlying acceptor film is dictated by CNTs’ propensity to aggregate into parallel arrays (bundles) and occurs over a distance of 5 – 10 nanometers.

 

Ultimately, future work building on the fundamentals established in this project is expected to lead to new classes of photovoltaic materials and devices that will lead to new intellectual property and new high-performance, low-cost photovoltaic solar cells and photodetector technologies based on stable, semiconducting CNTs as the active, light-absorbing components.

 

This project supported one graduate student research assistant in years 2 through 5 of his Ph.D. The work was disseminated to the scientific community via 7 peer-review journal publications.  4 additional papers are currently under review or have been accepted for publication that are on related research. 9 invited and 8 contributed oral conference presentations and 2 contributed poster presentations were also given on this work. This project afforded the supported graduate student the opportunity to conduct research and training at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory, and since graduating in 9/2013 the graduate student has taken a position in the semiconductor electronics industry.  

 

The principal investigator received the American Chemical Society (ACS) Arthur K. Doolittle Award in Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering in 2012, based on work for this project.
